1050454031385149440.text: 17/ I won't get into things like Transparency, Censorship-resistance, and other benefits blockchains provide. This tech is obviously fundamentally better. Is it where it needs to be today? No. That's why many smart folks are leaving "fintech" and rebuilding it with crypto. /fin

1050453246177943552.text: 16/ the fundamental difference with blockchains is that not only are numbers moving, but the value itself is in those numbers, moving with it. No percentage charges with blockchains, period.

1050453021694615559.text: 15/ Let's compare COST. Average fiat payment in "fintech" has a cost of $0.30 + 2.9% PER CARD SWIPE. So great for the consumer isn't it? This is the world @nouriel wants you to live in, where companies get to charge you money for moving numbers around in a database.

1050452273686560769.text: 14/ Then again the network wouldn't be valuable once it's 51% owned and manipulated by a nation-state as such, so the "hack" would be ineffective after spending close to $100 billion to take it over.

1050452096468815873.text: 13/ PoW blockchains can't be hacked in traditional ways, but rather through 51% attacks. Which at this point to take over the Bitcoin network, you would have to have so much computation power that only nation-states can do it, if so.

1050451800506159105.text: 12/ Security. Your favorite fintech solution is as secure as your data in Equifax. It will get hacked as long as it's valuable to hack it.

1050451452894871552.text: 11/ Blockchains have consensus algorithms that practically all participants of a network agree on. Consensus is part of the system with blockchain.

1050451311869739008.text: 10/ Another one is CONSENSUS. How do two banks settle transactions when their records contradict each other? How does Fintech solve this? It DOESN'T. This is another problem in Finance. Banks spend lots of money to resolve issues like this ALL. THE. TIME.

1050450755302432769.text: 9/ Blockchains solve this problem, as trust is no longer necessary, and only one of the double-spent transactions will be mined in the next block. One of the oldest problems in finance, solved.

1050450475802402817.text: 8/ Fintech simply DOESNT handle it, and the consumer bears the cost. This has manifested itself in popular "venmo scams" and all sorts of others in banking. There simply can't be a fix for double-spending as long as trust is still a part of the transfer process.

1050450138676830208.text: 7/ The often ignored, millenia-old "double-spending" problem in finance. For beginners, this means somebody having $100 in their account for example, and sending this to two people at the same time. How does Fintech handle this?

1050449846522523649.text: 6/ Fintech hasn't done anything to solve these problems, but rather presented consumer-friendly workarounds (which are still limited) that generate profit from the sender's funds during this time. Moreover, there's a hidden cost and other risks in handing over data and access

1050449334209273857.text: 5/ How about securities settlement? Securities are notoriously settled in 3 days after the exchange has happened hence the term T+3. On any given public chain, this would be near instant (same transaction speeds as sending money).

1050449069875884032.text: 4/ on Bitcoin blockchain, it would take 10minutes with a few dollars in cost. On Ethereum, 15 seconds with $0.02 cents in cost.

1050448850186641409.text: 3/ How long does it take to actually move money in Fintech? You have 3 options: ACH transfer (takes 2 days, no cost), domestic wire (4-24 hours during the week, US only, ~$25 avg cost), international wire (2-3 business days, ~$30 avg cost).

1050448249969147904.text: 2/ lets start by the fact that the word fintech didn't exist before Bitcoin. Nobody used it or understood it. But now the good stuff:
